rationale: Monocytes are white blood cells that circulate in the blood for a short period before migrating to the tissues, where they differentiate into tissue macrophages. These macrophages play a crucial role in the immune response by engulfing and digesting pathogens and cellular debris. Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell involved in specific immune responses, while neutrophils are the most abundant type of white blood cell and are primarily responsible for fighting bacterial infections. Plasma cells are differentiated B cells that produce antibodies.
outputs:
A. Monocyte

Rationale: Monocytes are a type of white blood cell that circulate in the blood and, upon entering tissues, differentiate into macrophages, which are cells that play a key role in the immune system by phagocytizing pathogens and dead cells.

question: A 6-year-old unvaccinated male is brought in with swollen ankles and puffy eyes. The parents state that they believe in a holistic approach to medicine and do not have a medical provider. The family reports that two weeks ago, the patient was sick with a fever and sore throat which resolved without issue. The patient is noted to be hypertensive for his age. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated creatinine. Which of the following is most accurate regarding this disease process?
rationale:
The patient in this scenario has post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This disease is most common in crowded areas and developing nations. It is rare in the developed world. There are approximately 470,000 cases globally, with approximately 5,000 deaths. While morbidity is high in older patients, the majority of patients do well and recover renal function. >90% of pediatric patients will make a full recovery.

Laboratory testing will reveal elevated blood urea nitrogen and creatinine, hypoproteinemia, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and low complement levels. Overall patients tend to recover their renal function and have a favorable long-term prognosis.

Antibiotics are used to prevent person-to-person transmission and prevent other cases of infection though they do not alter the patient's clinical course.

Morbidity is high in older patients, though the majority of patients do well and recover renal function. More than 90% of pediatric patients will make a full recovery.
A: It is most common in developed countries
B: Laboratory testing will reveal hyperproteinemia and elevated C3 (complement) levels
C: Antibiotics will shorten this patient's disease course
D: Young patients generally have a favorable long-term prognosis
outputs:
B

Rationale: The symptoms described are indicative of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), which is characterized by hyperproteinemia and elevated C3 levels following a streptococcal infection. PSGN is more common in developing countries due to higher rates of streptococcal infections. Antibiotics are used to treat the initial streptococcal infection, not PSGN itself, and while young patients can have a favorable prognosis, the hypertension and elevated creatinine indicate kidney involvement which can have long-term implications.

question: A midwife examines a woman following spontaneous vaginal delivery. Sheidentifies perineal trauma involving the vagina and perineal muscles but notthe anal sphincter muscle. How should the tear be classified?
rationale: This is a second-degree tear. First-degree tears only involve the perinealskin. Tears that involve the anal sphincter complex are classified as third degree tears. Fourth-degree tears involve the anal sphincter and the rectalmucosa . An episiotomy is a deliberate incision in theperineum made to facilitate delivery and reduce the risk of perineal injury.
outputs:
E. Second degree tear


Rationale: A second-degree tear involves the vaginal mucosa and perineal muscles but does not extend to the anal sphincter. First-degree tears involve only the vaginal mucosa, third-degree tears extend to the anal sphincter, and fourth-degree tears extend through the anal sphincter and into the mucosa of the rectum. An episiotomy is a surgical incision, not a type of tear.

question: A 61-year-old man comes to your office for a checkup. He currently feels well and has no focal complaints. He has a past medical history significant for wellcontrolled hypertension, and his gallbladder was removed 3 years ago in the setting of acute cholecystitis. He does not smoke and drinks one to two alcoholic beverages per day. Family history is remarkable for colon cancer in his mother at age 45 and a brother at age 49. He has a sister who developed endometrial cancer at age 53 .He has never undergone colon cancer screening and is interested in pursuing this.  Which colorectal cancer screening test would be best for this patient?
rationale: The patient should undergo screening colonoscopy, especially with his strongly positive family history of first-degree relatives developing colon cancer before age 50. Colonoscopy is the only test that can directly evaluate the entire colon and rectum. Most polyps can be removed completely at colonoscopy, and large lesions or masses can be directly biopsied. Virtual colonoscopy and barium enema combined with flexible sigmoidoscopy are good tests, but any positive findings on either of these tests would warrant further examination with colonoscopy. Barium enema alone is insufficient for screening. Fecal occult blood testing is helpful as a screening tool, but would be inadequate alone in this patient given his family history. The patient satisfies criteria for HNPCC, a syndrome seen in patients with germline mutations in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes. He has three first-degree relatives with cancer of the colorectum, endometrium, small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis (all of whom are first-degree relatives of each other). The colorectal cancers involve at least two  generations and at least one case was diagnosed before age 50. FAP involves a mutation of the  APC gene and results in dense colonic polyposis, mandibular osteomas, and universal colon cancer at a young age unless colectomy is performed. PeutzJeghers syndrome results in hamartomatous polyps of the gut as well as mucocutaneous pigmentation changes. Cronkhite-Canada syndrome manifests as GI polyposis, alopecia, cutaneous hyperpigmentation, malnutrition, and dystrophic fingernails. Turcot syndrome is a variant of FAP in which patients can also develop medulloblastoma, glioblastoma multiforme, and hypertrophy of retinal pigmented epithelium.
outputs:
E. colonoscopy

Rationale: Given the patient's family history of colon cancer at relatively young ages, he is at an increased risk for developing the disease. Colonoscopy is the most comprehensive screening test, allowing for visualization of the entire colon and the ability to remove polyps or take biopsies during the procedure.

question: Which of the following is the first-line treatment for a snakebite victim presenting with signs of systemic envenomation in sub-Saharan Africa?
rationale: In an African setting, oral rehydration solution (ORS) is the recommended fluid resuscitation strategy for patients with severe dehydration due to cholera, as it is effective, inexpensive, and can be administered easily even in resource-limited settings.
outputs:
A. Intravenous antivenom

Rationale: In cases of snakebite with systemic envenomation, especially in regions like sub-Saharan Africa where certain venomous snakes are prevalent, the first-line treatment is the administration of antivenom. This is because antivenom is specifically designed to neutralize the effects of the venom, thereby reducing the severity of the envenomation and preventing further complications.

question: A 65-year-old Hausa farmer presents with a 2-week history of restricted ankle dorsiflexion, paresthesia, and pain in his right foot. On examination, the patient has localized distal ischemia, contracture, and gangrene of the right toes. He is diagnosed with an aneurysm of the dorsalis pedis artery. This artery supplies 2 closely associated muscles on the dorsum of the foot. What is the nerve supply of these 2 muscles?
rationale:
A dorsalis pedis artery (DPA) aneurysm can restrict ankle dorsiflexion, paresthesia, pain, localized distal ischemia, contracture, and gangrene of the toes.

The DPA supplies 2 closely associated muscles on the dorsum of the foot: the extensor hallucis and the extensor digitorum brevis.

These muscles receive their vascular supply from the DPA and their innervation from the deep peroneal nerve.

The deep peroneal nerve is one of the main branches of the common peroneal nerve.
outputs:
A


Rationale: The dorsalis pedis artery supplies blood to the dorsal aspect of the foot, including the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion. The deep peroneal nerve innervates the muscles on the dorsum of the foot that are involved in dorsiflexion, such as the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, and extensor digitorum longus. The other options (B, C, D, and E) innervate different regions of the foot and are not primarily responsible for dorsiflexion.

question: Which of the following is a common etiological factor for the development of cervical cancer in African women?
rationale: HPV infection, particularly with high-risk HPV types, is the primary cause of cervical cancer in African women.
outputs:
A. Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection

Rationale: HPV, particularly high-risk strains such as HPV 16 and 18, is the most significant risk factor for the development of cervical cancer worldwide, including among African women. The other options listed are associated with other health conditions but are not the primary etiological factors for cervical cancer.

question: Which condition is characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, leading to wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath?
rationale: Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, resulting in symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath.
outputs:
B. Asthma

Rationale: Asthma is the condition that is specifically characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, which can cause symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs, COPD is a group of lung diseases that block airflow, and pulmonary embolism is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs.

question: A patient from an African community presents with gynecomastia. Which of the following surgical procedures is commonly performed for the treatment of gynecomastia?
rationale: Mastectomy, or surgical removal of breast tissue, is commonly performed for the treatment of gynecomastia, especially in cases of glandular enlargement.
outputs:
C. Breast reduction

Rationale: Gynecomastia is the enlargement of breast tissue in males, and the most appropriate surgical procedure to treat this condition is a breast reduction, which aims to remove excess breast tissue and tighten the skin. Mastectomy is not typically used for gynecomastia as it involves the removal of breast tissue and is more associated with breast cancer treatment. Liposuction is used to remove fat but does not specifically target breast tissue. Breast augmentation is used to increase breast size, which is the opposite of what is needed for gynecomastia. A breast lift is primarily for aesthetic reasons to raise and reshape sagging breasts, not for reducing breast tissue.

question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by the deposition of urate crystals in the joints, leading to acute inflammatory arthritis?
rationale: Gout is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints, leading to acute inflammatory arthritis. It commonly affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint but can involve other joints as well.
outputs:
B. Gout

Rationale: Gout is the condition that is characterized by the deposition of urate crystals in the joints, which can lead to episodes of acute inflammatory arthritis, known as gout flares. The other conditions listed have different pathophysiological mechanisms and clinical presentations.

question: A 23-year-old man presents with a heart-racing sensation for the past hour. A history of present illness reveals that he has felt this before, and it feels similar to his prior panic attacks. He was prescribed medication for when he is feeling anxious but has not taken it today. His vital signs are heart rate 110 bpm, respiratory rate 26 breaths/min, oxygen saturation 100% on room air, and temperature 98.6 °F (37 °C). When taking his blood pressure, you notice that his hand begins to spasm. What is the most likely cause of this observation?
rationale:
Although Trousseau's sign is most commonly seen in hypocalcemia, hyperventilation can cause carpopedal spasms.

Hyperventilation can cause the body to become alkalotic via the exhalation of carbon dioxide.

In metabolic alkalosis, calcium is more readily bound to albumin, thus decreasing the amount of free-ionized calcium in the blood. In exchange for the calcium, albumin releases its bound hydrogen ion.

Although hypocalcemia is present in sepsis, this patient who is afebrile and has a history of panic attacks is more likely to be having carpopedal spasms in the setting of hyperventilation.
outputs:
E

Rationale: The patient's symptoms and history are consistent with a panic attack, which can cause sympathetic nervous system activation leading to increased heart rate and hand spasms. The other options are less likely given the context provided.

question: The recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates the following muscles of the larynx except
rationale: This is because the cricothyroid muscle is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
outputs:
A. Cricothyroid

The cricothyroid muscle is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X), not the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

question: A 55-year-old woman is brought in by her son after an episode of seizures. She has a past medical history of poorly controlled hypertension and a 20-pack-year smoking history. The son denies any prior history of seizures. A head CT scan shows a large left frontal intracerebral hematoma and subarachnoid hemorrhage. Cerebral angiography reveals a saccular contrast-filled formation in the area of the anterior cerebral artery. The patient is intubated and sedated for airway protection. Which of the following is a risk factor for developing this condition?
rationale:
Patients with berry aneurysms present with the most severe manifestation of a major aneurysmal rupture, such as a subarachnoid hemorrhage to minor hemorrhage, also known as a sentinel bleed, non-hemorrhagic scenarios, or asymptomatic situations in which the aneurysm is found incidentally.

Seizures present in 25% of aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhages. They may be focal or generalized.

Genetic factors in the development of the berry aneurysm include connective tissue disorders that weaken artery walls, polycystic kidney disease, arteriovenous malformations, and a history of an aneurysm in 2 or more first-degree family members.

Other risk factors are untreated high blood pressure, cigarette smoking, and drug use, including cocaine and amphetamines, which via their toxidrome, increase blood pressure extremely, heavy alcohol intake, and heavy caffeine intake.
outputs:
B. Oral contraceptive

The patient's presentation is consistent with a cerebral aneurysm that has ruptured, leading to subarachnoid hemorrhage and intracerebral hematoma. Oral contraceptives are a well-known risk factor for the development of cerebral aneurysms due to their effect on the coagulation system and blood vessel walls.

question: A 25-year-old African patient presents with a history of recurrent infections, including otitis media, sinusitis, and pneumonia. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of serum immunoglobulin G (IgG), IgA, and IgM. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
rationale: Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID) is characterized by low levels of serum immunoglobulins and recurrent infections, often presenting in young adults.
outputs:
A. Common variable immunodeficiency (CVID)

Rationale: The patient's symptoms of recurrent infections and low levels of multiple immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, and IgM) are characteristic of Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID), which is the most likely diagnosis among the options provided.

question: Use of local anaesthetic agent with epinephrine is relatively contraindicated in these sites except:
rationale: Local anesthetics with epinephrine are relatively contraindicated in areas with limited blood supply or end arteries. This is because epinephrine acts as a vasoconstrictor, narrowing blood vessels and potentially reducing blood flow to the already-limited supply in these areas. The elbow joint has a good blood supply. While caution is advised, epinephrine use with a local anesthetic might be acceptable depending on the specific situation and the amount used.
outputs:
C. Ears

Rationale: Epinephrine is used in local anesthetic agents to constrict blood vessels and reduce bleeding, but it is contraindicated in areas with end-arteries like fingers, toes, and penis because it can cause ischemia. However, the ears have a richer blood supply and are less likely to suffer from ischemic complications when epinephrine is used.

question: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his roommate after he was found staggering towards the living room. He reports dizziness, nausea, confusion, headache, mild chest pain, shortness of breath, and poor balance. He states that he left the heater in his room, running for a couple of hours while working on his project before he experienced these symptoms. His past medical history is unremarkable. His vitals show a temperature of 98.8 F (37.1 C), pulse 96/min, respiratory rate 22/min, and blood pressure 124/86 mmHg. He is afebrile, acyanotic, but appears somnolent. Conjunctival pallor is absent. Clear vesicular breath sounds are noted on auscultation with normal S1 and S2 heart sounds. CO-oximeter reveals a carboxyhemoglobin of 15%, while his oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. Which of the following treatment options should be given to the patient?
rationale:
This patient has carbon monoxide poisoning secondary to his prolonged exposure to this substance through the heating system in his room. Carbon monoxide binds on complex IV of the electron transport chain which aids in oxidative phosphorylation. Other sources of carbon monoxide poisoning include wood-burning, exhaust fumes, methylene chloride from paint thinners, and building fires. However, cyanide poisoning can also occur from building fires, it is advisable to exercise caution when establishing the diagnosis of such patients.

The inhibition of this complex leads to a decrease in ATP production. Other mechanisms include the binding of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin, which increases the affinity of oxygen to the remaining sites (hemoglobin acts as a tetramer). As a result, oxygen delivery to tissues is decreased, and the oxygen dissociation curve shifts to the left.

Clinically, patients may present with dizziness, nausea, confusion, headache, mild chest pain, shortness of breath, seizure, poor balance, cardiac arrhythmia, and can even result in death. Oxygen saturation is often normal in these patients. So it is vital to check their carboxyhemoglobin levels.

Diagnosis is often made from the patient's history, physical exam findings, and carboxyhemoglobin levels. Treatment is done with 100% supplemental oxygen or hyperbaric oxygen.
outputs:
D. Sodium nitrite

Rationale: The patient's symptoms and the elevated carboxyhemoglobin level indicate carbon monoxide poisoning, which is consistent with the history of exposure to a running heater. Sodium nitrite is used in the treatment of carbon monoxide poisoning to help convert hemoglobin into carboxyhemoglobin, which then binds to the remaining sites on hemoglobin, displacing carbon monoxide and allowing for the formation of methemoglobin, which has a higher affinity for carbon monoxide and thus helps to displace it from hemoglobin.

question: A hernia is a normal protrusion of part or the whole of a visceral structure through a natural or artificial defect?
rationale: A hernia is an abnormal protrusion not normal. So the correct answer is false
outputs:
A. True

Rationale: A hernia occurs when an organ or fatty tissue squeezes through a weak spot in a surrounding muscle or connective tissue called fascia. The term "normal protrusion" in this context refers to the fact that hernias are a natural occurrence, although they are often considered abnormal due to their potential to cause discomfort or complications.

question: A 33-year-old G1P1 woman presents to her gynecologist for a Pap smear. It has been several years since a physician has last seen her. She is not currently sexually active, but takes oral contraceptives. Her vaginal examination is normal, but her Pap smear shows moderate-grade cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN II), a precursor of cervical cancer. The patient undergoes colposcopy and biopsies taken at that time are confirmatory for CIN II. What is the appropriate management of this patient?
rationale: The correct answer is B. Dysplastic cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN II) cells most often will undergo malignant transformation if not treated. The mean time to malignant transformation is 4 years for CIN II, but occasionally can be much quicker. While CIN I lesions can be monitored with colposcopy every 3–4 months, the standard of care for CIN II and III lesions is local excision by a loop electrosurgical excision procedure. This procedure can often be performed in the gynecologist’s office.
outputs:
B. Loop electrosurgical excision procedure

Rationale: The patient has been diagnosed with CIN II, which is a high-grade precancerous lesion. The standard management for CIN II is a loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) or a conization procedure to remove the affected tissue and prevent the development of cervical cancer. Continued annual Pap smears (A) would not be sufficient for this high-grade lesion. Radiation therapy (C) is not indicated for CIN II. Serial colposcopies (D) would not be as definitive as a LEEP procedure for removing the lesion. Total abdominal hysterectomy (E) is an overtreatment for CIN II, especially in a patient who is not currently sexually active and has no other indications for such a procedure.

question: Which of the following statements about pleomorphic adenoma of the lacrimal gland is false?
rationale: Pleomorphic adenoma of the lacrimal gland is a benign tumor that arises from the epithelial cells of the gland. It is known to have a tendency to recur, and in some cases, these recurrences can transform into malignancy. However, it is not known to resolve spontaneously. Therefore, the statement that it can resolve spontaneously is false.
A: It can recur in a diffuse manner
B: It can transform to a malignant tumor if present long enough.
outputs:
C. Recurrences can transform to malignancy

Rationale: Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign tumor, and while recurrences are possible, they do not inherently transform into malignancy.

question: An 18-year-old female student is brought to JUTH emergency department due to drug overdose. Which of the following routes of administration is the most desirable for administering the antidote for the drug overdose
rationale: The intravenous route of administration is the most desirable because it results in achievement of therapeutic plasma levels of the antidote rapidly
outputs:
E. Intravenous

Rationale: In cases of drug overdose, the fastest and most efficient way to administer an antidote is intravenously. This method allows the antidote to be delivered directly into the bloodstream, providing immediate action and rapid onset of therapeutic effects.

question: Which of the following gut structures are listed in the correct order that food would pass through them, from input to exit?
rationale: Jejunum is before the ileum; food does not pass through the pancreas; duodenum is before the ileum.
A: Pyloric sphincter, ileum, jejunum, transverse colon.
B: Pancreas, jejunum, ascending colon, sigmoid colon.
C: Ileum, duodenum, descending colon, ascending colon.
outputs: D

question: Which of the following is the most common cause of acute myocardial infarction (AMI)?
rationale: Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of AMI.
outputs:
A. Atherosclerosis

Rationale: Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of acute myocardial infarction because it leads to the buildup of plaques in the coronary arteries, which can eventually rupture and cause a blockage, resulting in a heart attack.

question: Which childhood condition is commonly associated with a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash?
rationale: Fifth disease presents with a rash resembling a "slapped cheek," followed by a lace-like rash on the trunk and limbs.
outputs:
C. Fifth disease

Rationale: Fifth disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by parvovirus B19 and is known for its distinctive "slapped cheek" rash appearance in children.

question: The general indications for the use of chemical and physical restraint include all except
rationale: When it comes to the use of chemical and physical restraints, they are generally not used at the patient's request. This is because restraints are implemented to ensure the safety of the patient, the healthcare providers, and others in the environment. The main indications for using restraints include preventing significant harm to the emergency department environment, allowing proper evaluation, investigation, and treatment of the patient, facilitating the taking of a police blood alcohol sample if needed, and most importantly, preventing imminent harm to the patient or others.
B: to prevent s significant harm to the environment of the emergency department
C: to allow evaluation, investigation and treatment of the patient
D: to facilitate taking of a police blood alcohol sample
E: prevent imminent harm to the patient or to others
outputs:
B

The use of restraints is not indicated to prevent significant harm to the environment of the emergency department; restraints are used for patient safety and care, not environmental protection.

question: A 62-year-old female presents with severe pain and blurry vision in her right eye for the past 15 hours. On slit-lamp examination, there is conjunctival hyperemia, a cloudy cornea, and a shallow anterior chamber. The pupil is mid-dilated and minimally reactive. The intraocular pressure (IOP) of her right eye is 45 mmHg. Which of the following is the best initial treatment option?
rationale:
Acute angle closure is an ocular emergency that needs immediate treatment. Early diagnosis and appropriate intervention improve patient outcomes.

In acute angle-closure, intraocular pressure (IOP) is increased by more than 21mmHg (normal is from 12 mmHg to 22 mmHg). Along with increased IOP, one of the following symptoms/signs may be present. There is often moderate to severe ocular pain, nausea or vomiting, and characteristic slit-lamp findings, including the mid-dilated reactive pupil, conjunctival congestion, corneal edema, and shallow anterior chamber.

The goal of medical treatment is to lower intraocular pressure (IOP) and then break any pupil block mechanism (laser peripheral iridotomy or iridoplasty). Topical, oral, or intravenous carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (such as acetazolamide), topical beta-blockers (timolol), cholinergic parasympathomimetics (pilocarpine), topical alpha-agonists (brimonidine, apraclonidine), and intravenous mannitol are treatment options to acutely lower the intraocular pressure. Oral beta-blocker medications have minimal effect on intraocular pressure acutely.

Antibiotics and local anesthetics have no role in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma.
A: Timolol and pilocarpine eye drops, and oral acetazolamide
outputs:
A. Timolol and pilocarpine eye drops, and oral acetazolamide

Rationale: The patient's symptoms and signs are indicative of acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is a medical emergency. The best initial treatment is to lower the intraocular pressure (IOP) quickly. Timolol (a beta-blocker) and pilocarpine (a miotic agent) are used to decrease IOP by reducing aqueous humor production and opening the blocked drainage angle, respectively. Oral acetazolamide is an oral carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that also decreases aqueous humor production. The other options are either not first-line treatments for acute angle-closure glaucoma or are not appropriate for the immediate management of this condition.

question: Mr Wilson is a 64yr old gentleman who saw his GP with SOB and a productive cough. He has attended the practice multiple times in the last few years for similar problems, particularly in winter. He explains he normally coughs a lot, bringing up a small amount of white sputum but currently is much more SOB and producing large volumes of green sputum. He is an ex-smoker with a 20 pack year history, and used to work as a pub landlord. His GP treats him with a course of antibiotics for a chest infection, which is very effective. She also refers him for pulmonary functions tests (PFTs) given the recurrent nature of his symptoms. The results of his PFTs post bronchodilation are as follows: FVC: 3.58 (predicted value 3.76 litres) 95% FEV1: 1.9 (predicted value 2.94 litres) 65% FEV1/FVC ratio: 0.53. What is this pattern consistent with?
rationale: A reduced FEV1 and FEV1/FVC is consistent with an obstructive picture. As FVC is within normal limits there is no evidence for a restrictive pattern. This fulfills the NICE criteria for COPD, but would be classed as moderate COPD (FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 50-79% predicted). The history itself points towards a diagnosis of COPD which is an obstructive disease, however you should be able to answer this question with the PFT results only.
E: Severe COPD with limited response to bronchiodilation
outputs:
C. Obstructive disease

Rationale: The PFT results show a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (less than 70%), which is indicative of an obstructive lung disease. The significant difference between the measured and predicted values for FVC and FEV1 also suggests a restrictive component, but the primary issue is the obstruction, as evidenced by the low FEV1/FVC ratio.

question: A 54-year-old woman undergoes urgent preoperative evaluation before resection of a partially obstructing mass in the descending colon. She has lost 9 kg (20 lb) over the past 6 months. Her history includes moderately severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) but no known coronary artery disease. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily. Her only medication is a combined ipratropium–albuterol oral inhaler. On physical examination, she appears ill. The blood pressure is normal. Weight is 48.9 kg (108 lb). Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On cardiopulmonary examination, the lungs are clear, with distant breath sounds and a prolonged expiratory phase, and the heart has a regular rhythm without murmur or gallop. On abdominal examination, high-pitched bowel sounds are heard, and a 6-cm mass, tender to palpation, is detected in the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory tests are normal except for a hemoglobin of 10.0 g/dL (100 g/L) and a serum albumin level of 2.9 g/dL (29 g/L). The chest radiograph shows only changes consistent with COPD, and the electrocardiogram is normal. In addition to routine use of scheduled bronchodilator treatments and supplemental oxygen, which of the following strategies is most appropriate in preventing postoperative pneumonia in this patient?
rationale: Incentive spirometry is the most appropriate strategy to prevent postoperative pneumonia in this patient. This patient has several risk factors for postoperative pneumonia, including weight loss, COPD, and smoking. Incentive spirometry helps to improve lung function and prevent atelectasis, which can lead to pneumonia. It involves deep breathing exercises using a spirometer device to encourage deep inhalation and prevent lung collapse. Intravenous hyperalimentation and enteral hyperalimentation are not indicated in this patient as she does not have severe malnutrition. Prophylactic corticosteroids and antibiotics are not recommended for routine use in preventing postoperative pneumonia.
outputs:
D. Incentive spirometry


The patient is at high risk for postoperative pneumonia due to her chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), smoking history, and current presentation with low oxygen saturation and signs of respiratory distress. Incentive spirometry is a strategy used to improve lung expansion and prevent atelectasis, which is crucial in patients with COPD undergoing surgery to reduce the risk of postoperative pneumonia.

question: A 60 years fit gentleman has recurrent dislocation of the hip joint.After THA, he has abductor deficiency. The appropriate treatment inthis case isSelect one:
rationale: The appropriate treatment for this patient with abductor deficiency after total hip arthroplasty (THA) would be revision surgery with a larger femoral head and a constrained PE liner (option d).Abductor deficiency is a common complication after THA, especially in patients with prior hip surgery, neuromuscular disorders, or trauma. This can lead to hip instability, dislocation, and poor function.Constrained liners are designed to provide additional stability to the hip joint by limiting the range of motion and preventing dislocation. A larger femoral head can also improve stability and reduce the risk of dislocation.Resection arthroplasty (option a) is a salvage procedure for infected or painful hip replacements, and is not appropriate for this patient with abductor deficiency.Closed reduction and hip immobilization (option c) would not address the underlying abdu
B: Revision surgery with a smaller femoral head and a constrained PE liner
D: Revision surgery with a larger femoral head and a constrained PE liner
outputs:
D. Revision surgery with a larger femoral head and a constrained PE liner

Rationale: The patient has recurrent dislocations after Total Hip Arthroplasty (THA), which suggests that the initial prosthesis may not have been adequately sized or secured. A larger femoral head can provide better coverage and stability, reducing the risk of dislocation. A constrained polyethylene (PE) liner can also help prevent dislocation by limiting the range of motion of the prosthetic joint.

question: A sixteen year old girl presents with chronic diarrhea. Which o the following features suggests that she has irritable bowelsyndrome:
rationale: Ref: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (Page 920) Davidson’s  Principles and Practice of Medicine
outputs:
B. Abdominal pain relieved by defecation

Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS) is often characterized by a combination of symptoms including abdominal pain that is relieved by defecation, changes in bowel habits, and other gastrointestinal discomforts. The other options listed can be associated with various gastrointestinal disorders but are not specific to IBS.

question: A 79-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of chest pain. The pain has been occurring intermittently for 3 days. It is not associated with exertion, does not radiate, and is "dull" in nature. The physical exam is remarkable for obesity and lower extremity edema. The cardiac exam is normal. Your senior registrar asked you to perfrom an electrocardiogram (ECG) which revealed a left bundle branch block (LBBB). The patient has had several prior ECGs in the past as seen in the documentation in his hospital folder. They all showed LBBB similar to the present one. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
rationale:
The patient's left bundle branch block (LBBB) is not new; therefore, it is not an ST-segment elevation equivalent. ECGs showing LBBB do not have interpretable ST-T wave segments and there is no mention in this case regarding any positive Sgarbossa criteria. The patient has not been ruled in for acute coronary syndrome (ACS), therefore, calling a cardiac alert is not indicated.

LBBB, once present, is usually permanent. This patient has proven as much with his prior ECGs all showing LBBB. There is no clinical maneuver that can reverse LBBB.

There is no medical therapy that would reverse a left bundle branch block. Amiodarone is not indicated.

Checking a serum troponin is indicated in patients presenting with chest pain. For this patient to rule in for a non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI) he has to meet two of three criteria: chest pain, ST-elevation on ECG, and elevated troponin. The patient presently meets only one of these criteria, and his ECG's ST segments are uninterpretable due to his LBBB. A negative serum troponin would rule out NSTEMI. Serum troponin can rule in acute coronary syndrome (ACS) or provide prognostic information for patients with ACS.
A: Call a cardiac alert so the patient can receive an immediate percutaneous coronary intervention
B: Have the patient bear down and repeat the ECG
C: Administer a loading dose of amiodarone to the patient and repeat the ECG
E: repeat the ECG after a few hours
outputs:
D. Check a serum troponin

Rationale: The patient's presentation of chest pain, especially in the context of LBBB on ECG, raises concern for acute coronary syndrome. LBBB can mask the typical ECG changes seen in myocardial infarction, making troponin levels a critical next step to assess for myocardial injury.

question: Causes of tetany due to hypocalcemia includes.a. Gluten Enteropathyb. Hypoventilationc. Acute pancreatitisd. Pyloric stenosise. Addison disease
rationale: a. Due to malabsorptionb. Acidosis decrease ionize calcium concentrationc. Fat substance release cause reduction in ionize calciumd. Alkalosis increases calcium absorption e. Acidosis decrease calcium absorption
outputs:
E

Rationale: Tetany due to hypocalcemia can be caused by conditions that lead to low calcium levels in the blood. Among the options given, Addison's disease (option e) can lead to hypocalcemia because it involves adrenal insufficiency, which can affect electrolyte balance including calcium. Gluten Enteropathy (a) primarily affects the gut and does not directly cause hypocalcemia. Hypoventilation (b) affects oxygen levels, not calcium. Acute pancreatitis (c) and Pyloric stenosis (d) are not typically associated with hypocalcemia as a direct cause of tetany.

question: A 40-year-old man presents with hearing loss in his right ear. Past medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Vital signs heart rate 70 bpm, blood pressure 128/78 mm Hg, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and temperature 98.6° F (37° C). On physical examination, the ear canals are clear, and tympanic membranes pearly grey bilaterally. A tuning fork test is performed by placing the tuning fork on the vertex, and the patient states he hears better in the affected ear. What is the underlying cause of this patient’s hearing loss?
rationale:
In this patient, the Weber test lateralizes to the affected ear; in other words, it is heard louder in the poorer ear indicating conductive hearing loss.

Otosclerosis is the abnormal growth of bone in the middle ear. This bone prevents structures within the ear from working properly and causes conductive hearing loss. It typically begins in early to mid-adulthood. It is more common in women than in men.

Mild otosclerosis can be treated with a hearing aid that amplifies sound, but surgery is often required. In a procedure known as a stapedectomy, a surgeon inserts a prosthetic device into the middle ear to bypass the abnormal bone and permit sound waves to travel to the inner ear and restore hearing.

Further examinations and investigations such as otoscopy, audiometry, tympanometry, and imaging may be required to correctly diagnose the cause of the hearing loss and allow appropriate management.
outputs:
C. Otosclerosis

Rationale: The patient's presentation of conductive hearing loss, as indicated by the tuning fork test (better hearing in the affected ear), and the absence of other symptoms such as vertigo or tinnitus, makes otosclerosis the most likely diagnosis. Otosclerosis typically affects adults and can lead to progressive hearing loss. The other options are less likely given the patient's presentation: Labyrinthitis usually presents with vertigo, Meniere disease with episodic vertigo and tinnitus, Otomycosis would likely show signs of infection in the ear canal, and noise exposure would not typically cause unilateral hearing loss.

question: A 44 year old male presents with a “spot of red” medial to his lateral canthus in his left eye. He complains of slight irritation over the area, no changes to his vision and no associated symptoms. He is worried because it is not going away after two weeks, and he suffered sunburn on his face whilst on holiday. The hyperaemia blanches on administration of phenylephrine 10%. What is the most likely diagnosis?
rationale: A classic presentation of episcleritis is a focal hyperaemic injection without pain or decrease in visual acuity. Often it is antecedent to UVB light exposure.
outputs:
D. Episcleritis

The patient's symptoms of localized redness that blanches with phenylephrine, a lack of vision changes, and a history of sunburn are most consistent with episcleritis, which is an inflammation of the episclera, a layer of tissue between the conjunctiva and the sclera.

question: All of the following statements regarding central control of autonomic functions are correct except:
rationale: When there is a sudden drop in blood pressure, the baroreceptors send signals to the brain, and the brain activates the sympathetic system (not the parasympathetic system) to restore blood pressure to normal values.
A: Baroreceptors are pressure sensors located at  various cardiovascular sites.
B: The parasympathetic system is activated by the  CNS in response to a sudden drop in blood pressure
C: The parasympathetic system is activated by the  CNS in response to a sudden increase in blood  pressure.
D: The sympathetic system is activated by the CNS in  response to a sudden drop in blood pressure
E: The parasympathetic division is involved in  accommodation of near vision, movement of food,  and urination.
outputs:
C. The parasympathetic system is activated by the CNS in response to a sudden increase in blood pressure.

Rationale: The parasympathetic system is typically activated by the CNS in response to a decrease in blood pressure to help lower heart rate and blood pressure, not an increase.

question: What would be the appropriate course of action for managing a 17-year-old boy who developed symptoms including fever, photophobia, stiff neck, hemorrhagic skin lesions, and a decrease in blood pressure that began 6 hours ago?
rationale: The patient is likely suffering from meningococcal meningitis, which is an aggressive condition requiring immediate treatment to prevent fatal outcomes. While enteroviruses can cause a skin rash, they do not typically lead to hemorrhagic lesions. This clinical presentation is also known as Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome, and the drop in blood pressure may be attributed to adrenal gland bleeding.
A: Stabilize blood pressure first, then proceed with investigations including MRI of the brain, blood culture, and CSF analyses.
B: Obtaining an MRI scan can consume valuable time. Once blood pressure is stabilized, prioritize obtaining cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analyses for diagnostic purposes.
C: Obtain blood cultures, treat with intravenous antibiotics, maintain  blood pressure, and then initate investigations
D: Investigate with an MRI brain scan and CSF analysis, and then treat  for viral or bacterial meningitis depending on results.
outputs:
C. Obtain blood cultures, treat with intravenous antibiotics, maintain blood pressure, and then initiate investigations


Rationale: The symptoms described are indicative of a serious condition such as meningitis, which can rapidly progress and is potentially life-threatening. Immediate stabilization of vital signs, particularly blood pressure, is crucial. Intravenous antibiotics should be administered promptly to combat potential bacterial infection, and blood cultures should be taken to identify the causative agent. Investigations like MRI and CSF analysis are important but secondary to immediate life-saving measures.

question: 58. A 65yr old, with hyperuricemia, binged on alcohol last night, presented with painful red swelling of big toe. On exam, subcutaneous nodules around ankle, what are they called
rationale: The subcutaneous nodules around the ankle commonly seen in gout are called tophi. So, the correct answer is D. Tophi.
outputs:
D. Tophi

Rationale: Tophi are deposits of monosodium urate crystals that occur in patients with chronic gout, which is consistent with the patient's history of hyperuricemia and alcohol consumption (a risk factor for gout). The presentation of painful red swelling of the big toe (a common site for gout attacks) and subcutaneous nodules around the ankle further supports the diagnosis of gout and the presence of tophi.

question: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. What is the most appropriate initial management?
rationale: In the case of a gunshot wound to the abdomen, which can cause life-threatening internal injuries, the most appropriate initial management in an African setting is to perform an exploratory laparotomy to identify and address any internal bleeding or organ damage, rather than relying on advanced imaging techniques that may not be readily available.
B: Obtain a CT scan of the abdomen
E: Observe and monitor the patient's condition
outputs:
C. Perform an exploratory laparotomy


Rationale: A gunshot wound to the abdomen is a surgical emergency due to the high risk of internal bleeding and damage to internal organs. Immediate surgical intervention is necessary to assess and repair any injuries, making an exploratory laparotomy the most appropriate initial management.

question: A 20-year-old G1P0 woman at 8 weeks and 3 days gestation presents to the clinic after her first positive pregnancy test. The patient reports mild nausea with minimal vomiting, which has resolved over the past 2 weeks. The patient denies any major complaints at this time, including vaginal discharge, vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain, or any other issues. She is currently taking prenatal vitamins. Which of the following is the best initial step in the treatment of this patient?
rationale:
Patients with positive pregnancy tests should undergo ultrasonography to confirm intrauterine pregnancy.

After confirmation of intrauterine pregnancy, patients should be started on prenatal vitamins (if not already taken) and undergo a physical examination, laboratory testing, and counseling regarding the expected prenatal course.

Patients presenting with the first positive pregnancy test without confirmed intrauterine pregnancy must be worked up and evaluated for other signs and symptoms to rule out "pregnancy of unknown location" or ectopic pregnancy. This includes sonography to confirm location.

CT is not indicated for confirmation of intrauterine pregnancy. The patient does not meet the criteria to undergo amniocentesis at this time. The expected prenatal course cannot be discussed until a healthy intrauterine pregnancy is confirmed.
C: Review the complications that can occur during delivery.
outputs: E

question: An 80-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department (ED) 30 minutes after she fell out of her wheelchair at home. This is the second visit to the ED for a fall during the past 3 months. She lives with her daughter and son-in-law, who say they “do the best we can.” The patient has dementia, Alzheimer type, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Current medications are amlodipine, aspirin, atorvastatin, donepezil, long-acting insulin, and lisinopril. Five years ago, she underwent bilateral below-the-knee amputations because of infected ulcers of the feet. She uses a wheelchair for ambulation. Ten years ago, she underwent three-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 60 years. She drinks one shot of whiskey nightly. She is thin and appears ill and disheveled. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 2 L/min of oxygen by nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 95%. Physical examination shows temporal wasting. There are scattered ecchymoses over the abdomen and all extremities. No other abnormalities are noted. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial history to obtain from this patient?
rationale: Given the patient's presentation and medical history, including dementia, Alzheimer's type, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, history of smoking and alcohol consumption, as well as current medications and recent falls, the most appropriate initial history to obtain from this patient would be:(D) Respiratory symptomsThis is important to assess for any potential respiratory distress or underlying pulmonary issues, especially considering her smoking history and the possibility of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or other respiratory conditions contributing to her symptoms.
outputs:
A. Abnormal bleeding

Given the patient's history of multiple falls, use of anticoagulants (aspirin and donepezil), and the presence of ecchymoses, it is important to assess for abnormal bleeding as a potential contributing factor to her falls and current presentation.

question: A midwife is concerned about a baby in the postnatal ward. On examination of the baby, the left wrist is in extreme extension, and the hand has a 'claw-like' appearance.What is the likely diagnosis?
rationale: The signs described above are consistent with Klumpke's paralysis, which classically presents with a 'claw hand' where the forearm is supinated, the wrist extended and the fingers flexed.
outputs:
D. Klumpke's paralysis

Rationale: Klumpke's paralysis is characterized by weakness or paralysis affecting the muscles of the forearm and hand, leading to a 'claw-like' appearance due to unopposed extensor muscle action. This condition is typically associated with an injury to the lower brachial plexus.

question: Which of the following endocrine glands is responsible for regulating the sleep-wake cycle:
rationale: The pineal gland is a cone shaped gland responsible for regulating the sleep-wake cycle by producing the hormone called melatonin
outputs:
C. Pineal gland

The pineal gland is responsible for regulating the sleep-wake cycle by secreting the hormone melatonin, which helps control circadian rhythms.

question: What is the recommended first-line medication for the management of hypertension in adults of African descent?
rationale: Amlodipine is recommended as the first-line medication for the management of hypertension in adults of African descent, as it has shown better efficacy and tolerability in this population.
outputs:
C. Lisinopril

Rationale: Lisinopril, an ACE inhibitor, is often recommended as a first-line treatment for hypertension in adults of African descent due to its effectiveness and the evidence supporting its use in this population.

question: A 3 month old child has moderate fever and non productive cough and mild dyspnea. After course of mild antibiotic the condition of the child improved transiently but he again develops high fever, productive cough and increased respiratory distress. Chest X ray shows hyperlucency and PFT shows obstructive pattem. Most probable diagnosis is?
rationale: Fever, cough and dyspnoea in a child with initial improvement followed by worsening of symptoms is seen in bronchiolitis obliterans.
outputs:
D. Bronchiolitis obliterans

Rationale: The symptoms and the progression of the child's condition, including the transient improvement after antibiotics, the high fever, productive cough, increased respiratory distress, hyperlucency on chest X-ray, and obstructive pattern on PFT, are indicative of Bronchiolitis obliterans, which is a form of chronic lung disease that can occur in infants and is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the small airways.

question:
The X-ray finding which helps to distinguish Hirschsprung's disease from
congenital megacolon is
rationale:
The correct answer is:

C. Presence of a transition zone.

In Hirschsprung's disease, a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, a transition zone is typically observed on contrast studies such as barium enema or contrast enema. This transition zone represents the area between the aganglionic (affected) segment of the colon and the normal, ganglion cell-containing portion.

In contrast, congenital megacolon, also known as colonic dilation or congenital colonic dilatation, typically presents with generalized dilatation of the colon without a distinct transition zone. Therefore, the presence of a transition zone helps to distinguish Hirschsprung's disease from congenital megacolon on imaging studies.
outputs:
C. Presence of a transition zone

Hirschsprung's disease is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal bowel, leading to a transition zone where the normal and aganglionic segments meet. This is a key radiographic finding that helps differentiate it from congenital megacolon, where such a distinct transition zone is typically not present.

question: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of obesity and diabetes presents with generalized fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, and weight gain. Physical examination reveals dry skin, thinning hair and noted lethargy. His thyroid gland is found to be palpably enlarged on one side. Further diagnostic tests point towards primary hypothyroidism. Which embryological structure is responsible for the ectopic location of the patient's thyroid gland?
rationale: The thyroid gland originates from a primordium in the floor of the pharynx and descends into the neck via the thyroglossal duct, which normally degenerates. An incomplete degeneration can lead to an ectopic thyroid along its descent path.
outputs:
D. Thyroglossal duct

Rationale: The thyroid gland originates from the foramen cecum at the base of the tongue and descends to its normal position in the neck, following the path of the thyroglossal duct. If the duct fails to regress, it can leave behind an ectopic thyroid tissue, which could explain the patient's palpable thyroid enlargement on one side. The other options listed are related to different embryological structures and developmental processes not associated with thyroid gland formation or ectopic thyroid tissue.

question: 35-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with a 2-week history of hearing voices, experiencing hallucinations, and feeling paranoid. He reports that the voices are commanding him to harm himself and others. What is the most likely diagnosis?
rationale: Schizophrenia is a chronic psychiatric disorder characterized by symptoms such as hearing voices, experiencing hallucinations, and feeling paranoid.
outputs:
B. Schizophrenia

Rationale: The patient's symptoms of auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and delusions (believing that the voices are commanding him to harm himself and others) are characteristic of schizophrenia. While other disorders can have overlapping symptoms, the combination and severity of symptoms described are most indicative of schizophrenia.

question: Which of the following is a common etiological agent of Lassa fever in West Africa?
rationale: Lassa virus, belonging to the Arenaviridae family, is endemic in West Africa and causes Lassa fever, a viral hemorrhagic fever.
outputs:
C. Lassa virus

Rationale: Lassa fever is an acute viral hemorrhagic illness caused by the Lassa virus, which is endemic in parts of West Africa. The other options listed are viruses that cause different diseases: Ebola and Marburg viruses cause hemorrhagic fevers similar to Lassa but are distinct pathogens, while Dengue and Chikungunya viruses are responsible for dengue fever and chikungunya fever, respectively, which are transmitted by mosquitoes and not related to Lassa fever.

question:
. 
A 15-year old female presented to the emergency department with history of recurrent epistaxis, hematuria and hematochezia. There was a history of profuse bleeding from the umbilicus stump at birth. Previous investigations revealed normal prothrombin time, activated partial thromboplastin time, thrombin time and fibrinogen levels. Her platelet counts as well as platelet function tests were normal but urea clot lysis test was positive. Which one of the following clotting factor is most likely to be deficient?
rationale:
Clinical features of Factor XIII deficiency :-
History of prolonged bleeding from umbilical stump
Delayed bleeding
Recurrent abortions

Diagnosis (Investigations) :-
Prothrombin time and Activated partial thromboplastin time are normal
--Factor XIII is needed for stabilization of fibrin clot
--Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are not affected
Clot stability in 5M urea – qualitative test
--Normal clot remains stable in 5M urea
--But in cases of Factor XIII deficiency, the clot dissolves
--But it becomes positive only in very severe deficiency
Quantitative factor XIII assay – using photometry
outputs:
D

Rationale: A positive urea clot lysis test indicates a defect in fibrin stabilization, which is a function of Factor XIII. The other factors listed (Factor X, XI, XII) are not directly involved in fibrin stabilization.

question: What is the best course of treatment for a 23-year-old woman presenting with growths around her vaginal opening that have been itching and bleeding, with several broad-based lesions measuring 2 to 4 cm in diameter along the posterior fourchette, including one lesion that appears to have been bleeding recently?
rationale: The lesions are most likely condyloma acuminata, also known as venereal warts. They are squamous lesions caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. Microscopic examination reveals a treelike growth pattern with a mantle characterized by significant acanthosis and parakeratosis. Treatment options include local excision, cryosurgery, application of podophyllin or trichloroacetic acid, and laser therapy. However, podophyllum is not recommended for extensive disease due to its toxicity, which can cause peripheral neuropathy. For refractory condyloma of the vagina, 5-fluorouracil can be used. Medical treatments such as podophyllum, imiquimod, trichloroacetic acid, and 5-fluorouracil require weeks or months of therapy to achieve effectiveness. Given the patient's large, bleeding lesions, local excision is the preferred treatment option.
A: Self-application of imiquimod to the lesions by the patient
C: Weekly application of trichloroacetic acid in the office
D: Weekly application of podophyllin in the office
outputs:
B. Local excision

Rationale: The description of the lesions suggests a diagnosis of genital warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Local excision is a definitive treatment that removes the visible lesions and reduces the risk of transmission. Options A, C, and D are less invasive but may not be as effective for larger or more extensive lesions. Option E is not typically used for genital warts and is more commonly associated with treating certain types of skin cancer.

question: A 15-day-old baby is being evaluated for yellowish discoloration of the eyes. This started on the fourth day of life. Phototherapy is being done, but the symptoms are not improving. Birth history is insignificant. The mother states that his brother has some issues related to liver disease. Vital signs are pulse rate 128/min, blood pressure 96/55 mmHg, respiratory rate 27/min, and temperature 98.6F (37 C). Physical examination reveals a soft, non-tender abdomen and jaundice. Total bilirubin despite treatment is 18 mg/dL with less than 15% direct. What is the next step in the management of this condition?
rationale:
In most cases of mild neonatal jaundice, no treatment is necessary, and it resolves on its own within a few weeks. In cases of moderate or severe jaundice (TB over 15 mg/dL), phototherapy is a safe option.

Phenobarbital increases both the conjugation and excretion of bilirubin by stimulating the gene for the UGT1A1 enzyme that induces the production of conjugated bilirubin and thereby reduces serum bilirubin levels by 25%.

Patients with Crigler-Najjar type II syndrome do not require any treatment and can have management with phenobarbital. Also, for Gilbert syndrome, no medical therapy is needed, and phenobarbital has been effectively shown to decrease bilirubin levels.

The common medications used for the treatment of patients with Crigler-Najjar type I syndrome are phenobarbital, calcium (infusions), ursodeoxycholic acid, metalloporphyrins, chlorpromazine, and cholestyramine.
outputs:
A. Phenobarbital

Rationale: The clinical presentation is suggestive of neonatal jaundice with a high total bilirubin level that is not responding adequately to phototherapy. The presence of a family history of liver disease and the fact that the direct bilirubin is less than 15% suggest that the jaundice is likely due to physiological processes rather than biliary obstruction or hemolysis. Phenobarbital can be used to induce liver enzyme activity and promote the conjugation and excretion of bilirubin.

question:
A 40-year-old man has epistaxis and bruises easily. As a child he had excessive bleeding following tonsillectomy and teeth extractions. His mother
and sister had similar symptoms. The most likely diagnosis is?
rationale: Von Willebrand’s disease affects both males and females. Haemophilia disease mostly affects males only
outputs:
D. Von Willebrand’s disease


Rationale: The patient's history of excessive bleeding following surgeries and a family history of similar symptoms suggests a hereditary bleeding disorder. Von Willebrand’s disease is the most common inherited bleeding disorder and often presents with symptoms like epistaxis (nosebleeds) and easy bruising, which aligns with the patient's presentation. Haemophilia A and B typically present with bleeding into joints and muscles, and are less likely to cause easy bruising. Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) usually presents with isolated thrombocytopenia without a family history. Lupus anticoagulant is associated with antiphospholipid syndrome and not typically characterized by the symptoms described.

question: . Which of the following drugs is used for acute toxic effects of organophosphate cholinesterase inhibitors?
rationale: c) PralidoximePralidoxime (also known as 2-PAM) is used for the acute toxic effects of organophosphate cholinesterase inhibitors. It works by reactivating cholinesterase enzymes that have been inhibited by organophosphates, thereby reversing their toxic effects. Therefore, option c) is the correct answer.
outputs:
C. Pralidoxime

Pralidoxime is used to reactivate cholinesterase that has been inhibited by organophosphates, thereby countering the toxic effects. Atropine is used to relieve muscarinic symptoms but does not reverse the inhibition of cholinesterase.

question: A 25-year-old medical student from Ghana has a planned clinical rotation at a large community hospital in Nigeria. He is required to have various screening tests, including a TB skin test (Mantoux test). His history is significant for the BCG vaccine in childhood. Which of the following measures will help avoid false positive test results from the Mantoux skin test?
rationale:
There is a lot of controversy on the use of the Mantoux test in people who have already been immunized with BCG.

The interferon test relies on T cells releasing interferon when exposed to specific antigens.

This may help avoid false positives and unnecessary drug therapy.

A two-step testing procedure has been recommended to avoid false tests. In addition, the interferon-gamma release assays are now being used instead of the skin test.
D: Presence of granulomas in the lung
outputs:
B

Interferon-gamma release assays (IGRAs) are more specific than the TB skin test and are not affected by prior BCG vaccination, thus helping to avoid false positive results in individuals who have been vaccinated.

question: Iron overload syndrome, also known as Bantu siderosis, is a common cause of liver cirrhosis in Africa.
rationale: African iron overload syndrome, or Bantu siderosis, is characterized by excessive iron accumulation in the liver and other organs due to traditional iron-rich diets and genetic factors, leading to liver cirrhosis and other complications.
outputs:
A. True

Rationale: Iron overload syndrome, which can be caused by genetic conditions like hemochromatosis or repeated blood transfusions, can indeed lead to liver cirrhosis. The term "Bantu siderosis" is not commonly used in medical literature; however, the statement's essence that iron overload can cause liver cirrhosis is true, especially in the context of Africa where genetic conditions leading to iron overload might be more prevalent.

question: A 55-year-old man with a medical history significant for diabetes, hypertension, and a history of aheart murmur has recently moved to the area. He is here to establish care. Overall he states that heis generally in good health. He states that his diabetes has been well controlled with a last HgA 1 c of6.0 and reports that he has not had any chest pain, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, dizziness,or syncope. He states that in the past he has had to take antibiotics for his heart murmur and wouldlike a prescription prior to seeing the dentist. He denies having any allergies. On clinical examination,his blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 70 beats per minute, and his oxygen saturation is98% on room air. He has a 2/6 mid-systolic click, which is best appreciated at the apex with radiationto the axilla. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.Which of the following measures do you recommend at this time?
rationale: Patients at the greatest danger of bad outcomes from endocarditisand for whom preventive procedure are worth the risks include thosewith artificial heart IS; serious congenital heart conditions, includingunrepaired or incompletely repaired cyanotic congenital heartdisease; completely repaired congenital heart I or device during thefirst 6 months after the procedure; any repaired congenital heartdefect with a residual defect at the site or adjacent to the site of aprosthetic device; or a cardiac transplantation with valvulopathy.
A: Based on the ACC/AHA guidelines, the patient should receive antibiotics prior to dental procedures
B: The patient does not meet indications for antibiotic prophylaxis based on the new ACC/AHA guidelines
C: Recommend that the patient avoid any future dental work because of his heart murmur
D: Recommend an echocardiogram and a left/right heart catheterization for further evaluation of the patient's heart murmur prior to any dental procedures
outputs:
B

The new ACC/AHA guidelines state that antibiotic prophylaxis for dental procedures is not recommended for patients with aortic valve disease unless they have a history of infective endocarditis. This patient's heart murmur and history of needing antibiotics for it do not meet the criteria for antibiotic prophylaxis.

question: Which of the following disease states is characterized by high trophic hormoneand low target hormone?
rationale: The combination of high trophic hormone and low target hormone indicatestarget gland failure.
outputs:
A. Cushing’s disease

Rationale: Cushing's disease is characterized by high levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) due to a pituitary adenoma, which leads to increased cortisol production. However, the feedback mechanism may be impaired, resulting in low levels of cortisol (target hormone) in the blood.

question: Causes of short stature in childhood includes.a. Klinefelter's syndromeb. Turners syndromec. Emotional deprivationd. Cushing's syndromee. Hypothyroidism
rationale: a. May cause gigantism b chromosomal abnormality causes failure to thrivec. Can affect child growth along  malnutrition d. Affect axial growth of long bones alongside obesitye. Decrease metabolism along with mental retardation
outputs:
D. True

Rationale: Hypothyroidism (e) is a known cause of short stature in childhood due to its role in growth and development. Klinefelter's syndrome (a) typically results in taller stature, not shorter. Turner's syndrome (b) can cause short stature, but it is not the only cause. Emotional deprivation (c) is not a direct cause of short stature. Cushing's syndrome (d) can lead to growth issues, but it is more commonly associated with other symptoms like weight gain and changes in skin appearance.

question: All but which of the following are tributaries of the coronary sinus of the heart?
rationale: The posterior vein of the left ventricle is not a tributary of the coronary sinus of the heart. It drains directly into the left atrium.The other options— the anterior cardiac vein, the great cardiac vein, the middle cardiac vein, and the oblique vein (of the left atrium)—are tributaries of the coronary sinus.
D: The oblique vein of the LA
E: The posterior vein of the LV
outputs:
E. The posterior vein of the LV

Rationale: The posterior vein of the left ventricle (LV) is not a tributary of the coronary sinus; instead, it drains directly into the right atrium. The other options listed are all tributaries of the coronary sinus.

question: Which of the following is the primary mechanism responsible for the development of atherosclerosis?
rationale: Endothelial dysfunction is the initial event in the development of atherosclerosis. It leads to increased permeability to lipoproteins, leukocyte adhesion, and expression of adhesion molecules, all of which contribute to the progression of atherosclerotic plaques. Smooth muscle cell proliferation, lipoprotein oxidation, platelet aggregation, and inflammation are secondary processes that further exacerbate atherosclerosis but are not the primary mechanism.
outputs:
E. Inflammation

Rationale: Inflammation is the primary mechanism responsible for the development of atherosclerosis because it initiates the process by which endothelial injury leads to the accumulation of lipids, immune cells, and fibrous elements, forming plaques. While the other options are involved in the progression or consequences of atherosclerosis, inflammation is the initial trigger for the disease process.

question: Ten years old boy complains of itching. On examination, there are mucoid nodules with smooth rounded surface on the limbus, and mucous white ropy mucopurulent conjunctivitis discharge. He most probably suffers from:
rationale: The given symptoms of mucoid nodules on the limbus, mucous white ropy mucopurulent conjunctivitis discharge, and itching are consistent with the diagnosis of bulbar spring catarrh. This condition is characterized by chronic inflammation of the conjunctiva, resulting in the formation of nodules and excessive mucus production. It typically affects young individuals and is more common in the spring season. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is characterized by small, raised lesions on the conjunctiva, while mucopurulent conjunctivitis and purulent conjunctivitis are characterized by pus-like discharge and inflammation of the conjunctiva.
outputs:
C. Bulbar spring catarrh

Rationale: The description of mucoid nodules on the limbus and mucous white ropy mucopurulent discharge is characteristic of Bulbar spring catarrh, which is common in preadolescent children.

question: A 65-year-old patient comes into the clinic with concerns about his recently elevated blood pressure. He reports generally good health, though he admits to taking "a few of his wife's pain-killers every now and then". He shares that she was prescribed "special pain-killers" by her doctor because she suffers from recurrent gastric ulcers. What is the likely etiology of his elevated blood pressure?
rationale:
Celecoxib inhibits COX-2.

COX-2 produces prostaglandin I2 (PGI2).

PGI2 causes vasodilation. A relative decrease in PGI2 can cause vasoconstriction.

Aspirin inhibits COX-1 and COX-2. While PGI2 synthesis will decrease, because the levels of thromboxane A2 also decrease, the balance of PGI2 to thromboxane A2 will remain.
outputs:
D

Rationale: Acetaminophen, commonly known as "Tylenol," is a medication that can be found in many over-the-counter pain-killers. Chronic use of acetaminophen, especially in higher doses, can lead to liver damage and has been associated with an increase in blood pressure due to its metabolic effects, including glutathione depletion. The other options are less likely because they do not commonly cause elevated blood pressure or are not associated with the medication described.

question: Which of the following is the correct management of a 2-week-old premature infant born to a hausa fulani woman, Baby is weighing 2.6 lbs (1200 grams) on no ventilatory support with no associated cardiac pathology and no evidence of pulmonary congestion or heart failure and presenting with continuous machinery murmur below the clavicle, radiating to the back and prominent precordial impulse, tachycardia, and bounding peripheral pulse on the physical examination?
rationale:
Since spontaneous closure may occur, immediate surgery is not warranted in this situation.

Infants over 2.2 lbs (1000 g) are likely to spontaneously close the ductus arteriosus before hospital discharge.

A patent ductus arteriosus does not require immediate pharmacologic treatment.

Watchful waiting and observing for signs of heart failure or pulmonary edema is appropriate for a small, patent ductus arteriosus in an infant greater than 2.2 lbs (1000 grams).
outputs:
D

Rationale: The described symptoms are indicative of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), a common condition in premature infants. Prostaglandin E is used to keep the ductus arteriosus open in these cases, allowing for better mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

question: During a clinic appointment, the patient is asked to sit with the arms dependent, hold her breath, and tilt her head back and turn it to the side. Meanwhilethe doctor is checking for presence or absence of a radial pulse. What is being described?
rationale: Adson’s test is used in the examination of thoracic outlet syndrome. In thisexample the examiner is checking to see if the radial pulse is obliterated. Compression of nerves causes wasting of muscles supplied by the lower trunk ofthe brachial plexus.
outputs:
C. Adson’s test

Rationale: Adson's test is a clinical maneuver used to assess for thoracic outlet syndrome, where the patient is asked to perform specific movements (sitting with arms dependent, holding breath, and turning head) while the doctor checks for changes in the radial pulse. This test helps to determine if there is compression in the thoracic outlet that could affect blood flow.

question: A 23-year-old man presents with night sweats, fevers, oliguria, and a large submandibular mass. Biopsy of the mass shows an aggressive tumor with sheets of lymphocytes staining positive for CD20, high levels of nuclear c-myc with interspersed macrophages. What is the mode of transmission of the virus associated with this malignancy?
rationale: The presentation described sounds like Burkitt lymphoma, which is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. The mode of transmission for EBV, which is typically associated with saliva and respiratory secretions, is option c) Saliva and respiratory secretions.
outputs:
C

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings are suggestive of Burkitt lymphoma, which is associated with the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). EBV is transmitted through saliva and respiratory secretions.

question: What is the best description for the area of the prostate that the carcinoma usually affects?
rationale: Prostatic cancer typically arises from the posterior lobe and on the periphery. This is why it is often asymptomatic as it does not compress the urethra producing no urinary symptoms at an early stage. The prostate is located anterior to the rectum. Thus, on digital rectal exam (DRE), a mass can be felt as the posterior and peripheral region is affected.
outputs:
A. Posterior and peripheral region

Rationale: Prostate cancer most commonly affects the peripheral zone of the prostate, which is located in the posterior region. This is why the PSA test, which measures the level of prostate-specific antigen in the blood, is often used for screening, as it can detect cancer in this area.

question: Select the situations in which the methods of sterilization or disinfection is not correctly applied
rationale: Hot air oven, a form of dry heat requires temperatures in the range of 180°C for 2 hours. This process is used primarily for glassware.
A: Plastic petri dishes: Hot air oven
D: Spillage of blood or serum: Hypochlorite solution
outputs:
C. Skin antisepsis: Chlorhexidine in spirit

Rationale: Chlorhexidine in spirit is commonly used for skin antisepsis and is considered effective. However, the other options listed are situations where the methods are not typically used correctly. Plastic petri dishes should not be sterilized in a hot air oven as they can melt. UV radiation is not effective for thorough theatre disinfection due to its inability to penetrate surfaces. Hypochlorite solution is appropriate for blood or serum spillage. Therefore, option C is the least incorrect, but it's important to note that chlorhexidine in spirit is actually a correct application, making all options technically incorrect in the context of the question asking for incorrect applications.

question: JM is a 10-year-old male who is sent to a pediatric neurologist for an evaluation due to receiving poor grades in class. JM’s parents have recently received complaints from his teacher that he is performing poorly in school and he is repeatedly caught not paying attention in class. Several times a day during class, JM is noted to be getting out of his chair and socializing with other students. He has also been getting into fights with some children, as he is being singled out by others and teased. JM is given a diagnosis of ADHD with impulsivity and irritability. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for management of the ADHD?
rationale: Dextroamphetamine is the only stimulant medication in the list that is approved for ADHD. Certain symptoms like fighting may improve with haloperidol and hyperactivity may improve with clonidine, but these agents would not improve the patient’s academic performance and the underlying problems.
outputs:
C. Dextroamphetamine

Rationale: Dextroamphetamine is a stimulant medication commonly used to treat ADHD by increasing attention and decreasing impulsiveness and hyperactivity in patients.
